subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: Being a visual learner, I ve put up what I hope visually captures the latest ideas discussed. I ll keep changing them as our notions evolve if only for my own
messageBody:
Being a visual learner, I've put up what I hope visually captures the
latest ideas discussed. I'll keep changing them as our notions evolve
if only for my own sake.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/american_english_template.jpg


I've made changes that, among other things:
- reflect the latest thinking about Roe (namely that it is being
treated as a pseudo-diphthong)
- reflect the SQUARE NEAR suggestion

I think the "pen" "pin" issue is not a total KIT DRESS merger but just
something that happens before "n". Such people will hear "pen" with
the KIT sound and thus use #26 I've omitted it from the upload until
we get a clearer idea.


Also, purely as a sanity check and to elicit corrections, I've also
made specific charts using the rules we've been discussing. I would
never claim they should remotely be considered final:

BCC English
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/bbc.jpg

California English (fixed from previous a version)
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/west_coast_us.jpg


American English as represented by Carnegie Mellon University
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/typical_us.jpg


New Zealand accent. I have no expertise in this accent: it was built
purely from looking up the NZ lexical sets and applying the rules
we've put together. As such it can show us if what we're doing makes
sense and maybe what we can (or can not) get from using lexical sets.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/new_zealand.jpg

Two points emerge for this version of NZE:
- the letter It #26 will have two radically different sounds:
for "kit" it will sound like [@\]
for terminal [i] sound in "happy" it will be uttered as [i]
- many of the other QS letters sound entirely differ from RP or
American usages.



---------------
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan<cowan@...> wrote:

> Since there are only eight lexical sets and 15 vowels, there will need
> to be some more or less arbitrary conventions to determine which vowel
> is used to write which set.

This must be done with the utmost care:

-If QS Letters have different sounds in different accents then
spelling must be the same everywhere.

-If spelling is different from accent to accent then the letters must
sound similar.

-If spelling is different *and* the letters have different sounds then
no one will ever be able to read anything.

If we're coming up with a solution where both spelling and letter
sounds differ we're going to have to be very, very clever to make it
work. We can't shove a lexical set under an arbitrary letter just
because we ran out of slots, the phoneme for that QS letter will have
to be the same across accents.



>
> Anthony Grahn scripsit:
>
> > - The CURE merge with THOUGHT/NORTH/FORCE would have to be done under
> > #33. But could anyone in America read Key+Ye+Awe+Roe as the word
"cure"
>
> "Kyor?" That couldn't be anything but "cure", so I wouldn't have
trouble
> with it.

But is this a significant improvement over Et+Key+See+Et+No+Tea for
"accent". I'm not being glib, it is an important question: I want to
make sure we are not trading known problems for unknown ones.





> CLOTH is analogous: it's either pronounced like LOT or like
CLOTH[typo for THOUGHT?].

In the diagram I uploaded, I allow CLOTH with LOT and THOUGHT and PALM
because:
- RP merges CLOTH and LOT with nothing else
- Standard American merges CLOTH and THOUGHT with nothing else
- Some accents merge CLOTH et al with PALM
